name: Stacking
description: Embark on an adventure to rescue Charlie’s family from the nefarious industrialist known only as the 'Baron.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP SP3 Processor: 1.8 GHz dual core CPU Memory: 1 GB RAM Graphics: 256 MB GeForce 8800, Radeon 3850, or Intel HD 2000 Graphics DirectX®:9.0c Hard Drive: 1.5 GB free HD Space Sound:DirectX Compatible Sound Card
recommended_requirements: OS:Windows 7 Processor:Intel Core 2 Duo at 2.2 GHz, or AMD Athlon 64 at 2.2 GHz Memory:1 GB RAM Graphics: 512 MB GeForce 220, Radeon 4550, Intel HD 3000 Graphics DirectX®:9.0c Hard Drive: 1.5 GB free HD Space Sound:DirectX Compatible Sound Card

reviews.review_text: A Review About Stacking

Lovely puzzle game with multiple solutions for each challenge, lively victorian/steampunk inspired world, entertaining story and cute interaction between dolls, each with its own skill (including farting and face slapping with a glove like a real gentleman) which you use in order to solve the puzzles and advance through the game, so that you can rescue your family that was kidnapped by the evil Baron for free slave labour. Oh, and not to mention the fancy classical soundtrack that is so fitting and really sets the atmosphere.  Only downside of this game is that it was too short.
Amusing, fun puzzles with multiple solutions, not too long. Definitely worth $10.
A charming little adventure game with loads of personality and multiple solutions for the same puzzles.   The only real downside is it can be beaten in 3-4 hours.

This is an extremely clever concept for a game that is very well-executed. There are multiple solutions for every puzzle, some of which can be quite tricky to get, and lots of interesting easter eggs. The game world feels alive with all the NPCs going about their business. My one complaint is that they didn't make good use of the middle doll in the stacking concept. Usually you only need the biggest doll in your stack, so you can fill up the middle between Charlie and that doll with anyone who's the right size. Other than that, though, this game is awesome and you should play it.

This game is definetly unique as puzzle games go. The Russian stacking doll idea is something I've never seen before in a game, and it works absolutely perfectly.   The gameplay itself is challenging, and it really makes you use your head to overcome obstacles. Some solutions won't be so easy ;)   The devs should keep on making games just like this. They are good at it!

Stacking is an unparralleled indie game experience  + The game mechanics are great : stacking in another doll goes fluently and offers a great variety of special traits to be used + The challenges are fun, and make sure you come back to solve all the solutions + The Hi-Jinks challenges are goofy and combined with the doll collection aquired at each stage it makes sure you explore everything there can be found in each stage + It's unique in it's genre  - Once everything has been found in a stage there isn't a reason to return to that stage, other than causing havoc with a peculiar doll

One of my absolute favourite games I've played recently, charmingly simple, yet some of the extra puzzles can get quite complex.  I played through it twice, to full complete it takes about 5 hours, and both times I spent it laughing and enjoying myself, never once did the game feel too long or too short.  Honestly one of those games that anyone can pick up and enjoy.

Really amazing game full of tons of content! Not only is this game super origional, the content in it is quite extensive. As well as pulling pranks, doing side quests, finding rare characters, there are many parts to main quests. Each main quest even has a bunch of different ways for it to be solved! This game is quite amazing.          YouTube™ Video:  Jupi Plays Indie Games: Stacking

Stacking - It's all about perspective  Double Fine did not disappoint - Stacking is truly one of a kind. A unique mechanic of possessing other characters by jumping into them is made possible through one fact - everyone is a Matryoshka doll!  It maintains a very stylish approach to storytelling, constantly being very meta and aware of itself which is what allows it to be genuinely funny.  I really liked the original campaign ending (I have yet to play the DLC), especially the way they handled the 'boss fight' (including the slo-mo sequence - I lol'd) & the message it conveyed.  In short: Witty, colorful and fun. Loved it!   V e r d i c t : AWESOMESAUCE, which means nearly perfect

This is the third game I own by Double Fine and once again it is a hit: it's quite unique and a fresh idea. Rather than making copycats, DF tries to do something original. I love the artistry behind this ... and in a particular way the music. Very well done!
Double Fine has been one of my favorite production studios, and this game is top notch. What a wonderful little story arc covered by an interesting, unique gameplay that keeps your attention.
Innovative and really interesting. Get it while it's cheap! :D
A good 'stacking' puzzle game with charming graphics and an interesting setting,
Very funny and challenging puzzle game. Hint system is great. If you get stuck it will gently guide you to the next step.
This game is so unique and it's fun to return to even after beating it, just to run around and do hi-jinks :P

Substantial enough to keep me entertained, clever enough to encourage me to find every solution to every puzzle and with the added DLC, a dynamic and intriguing world. The characters, the settings, the details great and small; like each Double Fine game I've played, I didn't want the leave the world behind when I wrapped up everything. Stacking is deceptively fun; it seems like it'd get monotonous and tedious, but there are so many small possibilities that even walking around and interacting with the characters doesn't have to be boring. The uniqueness of each doll is a stroke of genius; their abilities are unexpected and often quite funny, and as you start to recognize regulars from scene to scene you do start to feel a bit attached to them. Also, the protagonist is adorable. He's the tiniest kid in the world trying to save his family from peril, and he's so brave and optimistic that you want him to succeed. It's a feel-good story for every short kid like me.  One thing I will say, though, is that like many DF games the color scheme here is very brown and green, with rustic and dingy details. If these sorts of games make you dizzy or nauseated, steer clear, because this one's not very brightly colored and the camera is in constant, meandering motion to navigate around the surprisingly large environments. On my machine I wasn't able to use the camera without plugging in a controller, but once I did, Problem Solved and I had no other issues beyond that.  A short, sweet, clever feel good title. Sometimes creepy, often funny, and endearing. An absolute steal if you get it on sale.

To be fair, when I got this game from the Humble DoubleFine Bundle, I wans't expecting much from it. Turns out it's a pretty unique game. Control Nesting dolls in a story timeframe even older than TF2's and use their abilities to solve lots of neat puzzles. Try it out if you'd like, you might be surprised.
A quirky, funny matrioshka meets BioShock adventure.
Stacking is another Double Fine gem. I found it to be humerous throughout and had some fun puzzles. The gameplay however can get repitive quickly and it was the jokes that kept me going.
Stacking is another Double Fine gem. I found it to be humerous throughout and had some fun puzzles. The gameplay however can get repitive quickly and it was the jokes that kept me going.
This game will make you blow your stack because it's a good ol time
It is fun!

It's a fun little puzzle game where the gimmick is that you play as those little Russian dolls that stack on each other (I believe they are called Matryoshka dolls). The puzzles are quite creative and fun, and there are multiple solutions to each puzzle, allowing for a relatively high replay value. If you can't seem to figure out a puzzle by yourself, you can always get a hint from the menu. The third hint will literally tell you what to do to solve the puzzle, so only do that if you are completely stuck. There are also the 'Hi-jinx' that you can pull off in each area, and some of them are pretty funny as well.  Overall, I really liked it. It's definitely worth the $10 that they are asking for it.
You play as dolls that can go inside of each other.  IGN rates 10/10
An adventure with Russian Dolls, do you need any another reason?
For a adventure puzzler like no other, Stacking is worth your time. A great concept with a well written silly story from the Double Fine masterminds. I want to finish this game.
Nice little stacking game
Just awesome!
It's a lovely game with a very original theme and good gameplay. It's a must play if you like adventure genre.  PS: It does lack something but I can't tell what it is.

The main focus is the concept behind it. While the story is good, however weak and... yeah predictable, the gameplay is the main focus part of it. Life of a Russian doll. Go inside one and take control of them, movement and ability they have. Some of the puzzles are a bit confusing though, I even had to use a guide after completeling the adventures to get a hint or two. Controls have a slight delay to them, but could be just on my computer end.  Far as the DLC The Lost Hobo King: It's short but best played after the main story, as it takes place after the events of finding your family.

Good art, good characters, good story, good use of classical music. I liked the idea of stacking dolls, stacking into larger dolls with different abilities. My only complaint is too many (too long) cut scenes. There are some places in the game where you'll take 4 steps between cut scenes.

So creative and unique. It is a must play game. Multiple solutions to every challenge, and some will have you scratch your head only to slap your head when you realize how easy the solution was when you figured it out. Tim Schafer's humor is present, and of course, Double FIne quality is included. Simple and yet richly detailed worlds, I dare say this is even a better game than Psychonauts. You owe it to yourself to play this game.

Cute little puzzling adventure. 'nuff said I guess :]  You're basically a kernel matrioshka doll, Charles, able to stack on bigger and bigger dolls and using their special abilities to progress in game in order to save your family primarily and many other dolls as well. Or just to mess around and do 'hi-jinks'.  Just don't overthink what is happening or you may come to weird conclusions xD
Great game. The story-line and the sceneries are just geniues! And the characters, hillarious! For a good laugh, worth the money. A litle short, tho.
Great game. The story-line and the sceneries are just geniues! And the characters, hillarious! For a good laugh, worth the money. A litle short, tho.
This is a neat game. Nice victorian era setting with a cute concept. Simple, short. fun.  Good like all double fine games.

This was an absolute blast to play! My friend recommended this to me, perhaps even bought it, and I beat it all in one sitting. I love the dialog, the gameplay, the graphical design. Highly recommend.
Simple, engaging puzzle game that mimics a silent movie in parts, and a child's toy box in others.

Enjoyable and silly. The stacking dolls with the different abilities to get things to happen is fun to figure out, and the level of silly of some of it (for example, how useful someone with chronic and excessive flatulence can be) is beyond.  Especially worth it with the inclusion of the Hobo King quest line which is short, but silly.

It's a funny little puzzle game from Tim Schafer. The humor is the best part of the game. The neat thing about it is that there are more than one way to solve the puzzles, and it's challenging to try to figure all the different ways out. The sound effects for all the special moves certain dolls can perform are hilarious and often you'll find yourself just doing them to hear it. The graphics are neat and the music does a great job of fitting the scene. Both kids and adults should find things about this game to like.
A charming little 'collect-em-up' puzzler, recommended for anyone that's looking for a short and sweet ride.

A great story and game play, but sadly terrible short and quite a bad port form the consoles. It will make you have a good time replaying it do to it's multiple puzzle solutions, although some of it's 'replay values' are just dull repetitions on the same subject. An of course: bad-♥♥♥ Double Fine humour guaranteed.
Very fun, unique puzzle game. Lots of puzzles to keep you coming back even after you've completed levels.

My 2nd favorite Double Fine game (1st of course being Psychonauts), and one I come back to over and over again. Stacking is oozing with charm, humor, and a plethora of small details that make DF games my all-time favorites! If when you play an adventure/puzzle game you enjoy getting every snippet of dialog, trying every combination of items/abilities, collecting everything there is to collect, completing every side quest, and just generally playing with the silly antics the genre can afford, Stacking is a no-brainer.  The game is *not* a point and click adventure game, though the puzzle solving and general tomfoolery will feel very similar if you're a fan of the genre. Instead it's 3rd person, with a ridiculous amount of unique stacking dolls you can hop in and out of (all of which have unique abilities, even if they're just for playing around with, and often times have unique situational dialog), tons of silly challenges, and a fantastic 'solve the puzzle multiple ways' system that will have you scratching your head in the best possible way.  This is not a game to play if you want to just rush through and beat the 'main quest' (ie solving puzzles the minimum number of times, ignoring unique doll collecting, etc). 100% completion is where you will have the best time, and will really push your creative problem solving jiggly bits.  Overall fantastic game, a must-play if you like to solve logic problems in strange and wonderful ways, and a top tier gem of the geniuses at Double Fine. (also, I believe, a successful from-prototype-to-product of the 'Amnesia Fortnight' gamejam they do internally from time to time)
Clever idea.

Stacking has an unique concept in terms of solving puzzles and its adventures (the main story and the Lost Hobo King). What captured me to buy it though, was its art style and unique setting (olden times, about 1940s-1950s). Its puzzles were challenging enough for me to invest a lot of hours in it and its ability combos were interesting to use and watch too. Overall, this game for me is 9/10; a worthy buy of a game!

Utterly charming adventure game by Double Fine. Play as a matrioshka doll with the ability to jump into dolls exactly one size bigger and take control over them. Every doll has one unique power, and it is so much fun to play around and see how different dolls affect each other, and you get achievements for finding multiple creative solutions to puzzles, sets of related dolls, unique characters, secret locations etc. Brilliant stuff, dripping with charm, one of the best games of the year.
Cute and unique, both in gameplay and style. Short, but any longer and it would become far too repetitive. You know you're getting quality with a Tim Schafer game and here is no different.
Stalking is a puzzle game and it is also a fun game you can go anywhere you want at any time and you can find unike dolls There are lots of high jinks (personal challenges) That you can achive!
This game is great for its simplicity yet fun because of all the possibilities!
fun and addicting!!!!

Stacking is a short but fun game, where you play as a russian stacking doll. You (Charlie Blackmore) have the abillity to stack into other dolls (You're the smallest in the world). This feature allows you to solve the many puzzles in all of the avalible. My speedrun of Stacking took 1 hour and 36mins. So it is very short, but it is very replayable, as the many puzzles have different solutions. Maybe that's the reason I have it on three platforms...   I give Stacking a 10/10.
Pure, unadulterated fun. Plays excellently and looks wonderful. Although the cutscenes are a little longwinded, the game is truly charming.
Such a cool game...if you're creative and imaginitive you can't go wrong. If all you play is CoD and Madden, you're puny mind can't handle it.
A wonderfully inventive puzzle game, the game mechanic of stacking like Russian dolls is intriguing and original, and the setting is as fun and refined as we came to expect from Double Fine
It's an adorable game full of hijinks and adventure. Fun for the kids and older players.
Nice little game

This was a super fun puzzle/adventure game. You are a Russian nesting doll, and you get inside other dolls, each with their own abilities, and then use them to solve puzzles. Each puzzle has a variety of ways to solve it, plus there are a bunch of dolls to collect, and some bonus side mission things. I did 100% on the main game and the free DLC in 7.4 hrs and had a blast (was not planning on 100% when I started, but liked it so much). As with other Double Fine games, it has a great sense of humor and great art style.

One word describes this game: adorable. A clever puzzle game where you need to solve situations using each of the russian stacking dolls' unique powers. Puzzles consist in figuring out whose doll's power is necessary in the present situation. Each puzzle has three to five different possible solutions, each requiring different dolls. The storyline feels fresh and pleasant, in a children's tale way (but with added irony). I can't help loving all the characters, especially Levi the Hobo.   I recommend this game to anyone who is willing to try something different, challenging and, as I said, adorable.
This game is really fun. It's the kind of game that is enjoyable to 100%.
Nice 3D graphics with controller support combine to make this novel puzzler a diamond in the rough. If you enjoyed the offbeat approach of Psychonauts, you will undoubtedly enjoy Stacking as well.
Wonderful, charming, and with an excellent soundtrack. Another fantastic Double Fine entry!

Do you know how much it pains me to write this review? It's a nonviolent Double Fine adventure game about the cruelty of child labor laws during the Tammany Hall era based entirely around Russian matryoshka dolls. This should be the absolute peak of what I like. This review should be me wildly ejaculating onto my screen and extolling the virtues of Tim Schafer and Brad Muir and how much gaming needs more of everything they do.  Stacking's just sort of okay, and that is heartbreaking.

Stacking is a puzzle game coming from Double Fine studios.   You play as a russian doll called Charlie Blackmore who is on a mission to save his family from the evil Baron. To do so you can take control of other russian stacking dolls who all have their own unique abilities, like making shocking alarm noises or pumping out water.   The atmosphere of the game is very late 19th/ early 20th century with a lot of coal/steam power, victorian era fashion and a lot of the story being focused on child labour.  The controls are nice and solid and it really doesn't take long to master, however you can find that unstacking yourself will get you stuck a few times if you're not careful about where you do it. This wouldn't be an issue if there was someway to rectify mistakes, but if you find yourself stuck you will have to quit to the main manu and reload your save from there.   The game is only a few hours long if you play solely through the main story without going for 100% completion, but there are plenty of other things to aim for. You can try to collect all the unique dolls in the game, try and complete all of the doll stack series' as well as trying to find all solutions to each puzzle and completing optional challenges in each area.   There is also an extra adventure but it's basically the length of a single level, not that that's a bad thing as it prevents it from outstaying it's welcome.   Overall the game is well worth playing and considering that it's only going to kill a couple of hours if you blast straight through it won't require too much effort.   8/10
Good puzzle game. Very Fun. I loved searching for all the achievements.

One of the few games i enjoyed enough to want to 100% it and the DLC. Its a fun, charming game with thought provoking solutions to the same problem. Although doesn't seem like much at first, it quickly grew on me.
Basically doll porn
Interesting concept. Fun game. Loved the silent film aspect of the cut movies.

Adorable story about english matryoskas, enviromental issues during Industrial Revolution or something like that! It's cute. It's so cute. Really fun to play as other characters each with their own special skills to solve the puzzles.
This game is brilliant! Original in its looks and gameplay! It's like Hitman but for kids. >_<

Stacking is probably Double Fine's best executed game. While other Double Fine titles are lovable but somewhat clumsy, Stacking is very well put-together. The art direction, the design and the gameplay all come together in a witty, original and highly playable experience. While not particularly challenging, Stacking has both charm and substance.
Absolutely charming puzzle game with a unique setting. Great fun. Light recommendation.
A unique concept well executed. Stacking is a fun, well presented adventure suitable for all ages. Well worth your time and available for pennies on sale.
I really love this game. It's so cute! I haven't found all the secrets but have completed the overall game :D

I remember watching Sjin from the yogscast play this game 4 years ago, and that is when i literally didnt know how to use a computer, all i knew was how to go on youtube, anyways, i loved sjin at the time and i loved everything he played, i loved the games he played mainly cause he was soooooo good at all games, but this game was different, it really was , i didnt care that it was sjin playing, i just loved the game itself, and then idk when, i look in steam, and i see this game, and was like, OMMMMMGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGG, then i just bought it instantly, without thinking, and till now i love the game just as much , if not, them more than before,    what im trying to say is, really , BUY THE GAME, its awesome
It's not a massive or long game and the gameplay is incredibly limited (by design) BUT they really milk that for a lot of fun and silliness. It's easy, but still worth a play.
A puzzle game that involves humor and original ideas that make it fun an entertaining to play!
The story is great, the puzzles are funny! This game is one of the best

Stacking is an adventure game where you play as the smallest member of a family of nesting dolls. When your family is kidnapped you use your stacking powers of posession to use other dolls to solve puzzles.  The story is plain and takes a backseat to the puzzles themselves. The stages are very formulaic but still manage to keep things fresh by constantly introducing new dolls with new powers. Also, the asthetic design is strong, setting you in an industrial age silent movie for the cutscenes.  That said, I couldn't play the game for extended periods of time because I really just got bored with it. I did eventually finish the game but when I did I was glad to be free of it. If you love adventure games and the nesting doll posession tickles you then its a fine adventure game but for anybody else it is very difficult to recommend. I love Double Fine but safe to say Stacking is not among their best work.

I'm sincerely disappointed. The game has way too many cinematics (unskippable too) for my like. I understand that there is a story to the game, but it could've been told using many other ways other than endless cinematics and 2 minutes of gameplay inbetween.

really looking forward to this and was so underwhelmed, it looks like an active puzzler with an interesting design, but simplistic level design and poor game controlls let it down so bad. unless it's a big sale I'd find something else, at no point could I describe this game as fun or enjoyable throughout the entire experience

I don't recommend this game unless you're 14 or younger. it's just too infantile. Story, dialogues, character perks and reaction (burping, farting), everything is silly. Mechanics are original but in the end it's just shallow.  This is a kids game, not a puzzler for adults, despite the main theme, mature aesthetics, soundtrack etc.
After 3 minutes of intro video.. I personally expected something else wactching the trailer and stuff and i didn't undertand a single thing what i was supposed to do.  2/10
Putting people inside other people to control the people to make them handicapable since 19th century.   5/10
nice art style but not very diversified.
